Dear CYNTHIA Quintana-Montenegro:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff to resident ratio
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4127
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 10/8/2024 at 7:00pm, Youth A was outside and refused to
come back inside the building after dinner. Staff came outside to
check on Youth A every 30 minutes as he remained sitting at a
picnic table. Third shift checked cameras periodically to see if
Youth A was still outside. There was not enough staff to go
outside and check on Youth A. At 5:30am a staff went out to
check on Youth A and he was gone. Staff did not complete
variable interval eyes-on checks over night for Youth A.
Investigation Administrator and Case Manager Supervisor were
interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 10/10/2024. Both
reported knowing about the allegations but having no firsthand
information. They stated being informed that Youth A was sitting
outside at a table with other youth during dinner and refused to re-
enter the facility when the group went back inside after dinner.
Both reported staff were informed by Supervisor that they were to
monitor Youth A as best as they could. The also reported at
5:30AM staff went outside to talk with Youth A but were unable to
find Youth A. Administrator was unsure of the policy ratio of staff
to youth. They also reported Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, and
Staff 5 took half the youth upstairs around 8:00 PM and the other
staff who they could not recall stayed in the dining room/kitchen
area to monitor the remaining youth cleaning up the area. This last
staff (unidentified) and youth left the area shortly, thereafter,
leaving Youth A alone outside. They reported being informed by
staff (unidentified) that every 30-minutes staff would go outside to
ask Youth A to come back into the facility, but Youth A continued
to refuse. At 11:00 PM second shift ended and there were only
Staff 5 and Staff 6 working third shift. At first, Staff 5 and Staff 6
asked Youth A to come back inside but again Youth A refused.
Staff 5 and Staff 6 reported they came outside to check on Youth
A even though, they had 16 other youth in the building, they were
supervising.
2

Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
10/10/2024. Youth A reported eating dinner outside of the dining
room with other youth present. Youth A reported moving to a table
near the volleyball courts around 7:30PM with the other youth and
staff. Sometime after this the other youth went inside with staff
and Youth A informed staff but could not recall who, Youth A was
not coming. Youth A reported being upset and crying at the time.
Youth A reported missing Youth A’s family as a reason for Youth
A being upset. Youth A reported staff never questioned Youth A’s
crying and only checked on Youth A from a distance. Youth A
didn’t know the time and was unsure if second shift staff checked
on Youth A. Youth A denied third shift staff ever check on Youth
A. Youth A reported sitting behind a tree near the volleyball court
because Youth A was cold, and this shielded Youth A from the
wind. Youth A believed that sometime between 6:00AM and
7:00AM Case Manager Supervisor came outside and took Youth
A back into the facility. Youth A reported not being sure if Youth A
is safe at the facility because Youth A is being moved to different
facilities quite often.
Staff 1 was interviewed via phone on 10/23/2024. She reported
working at the facility the day of the incident and began her shift in
the morning. She reported being asked to work over until 8:00PM
because an afternoon staff had “called off” and extra staff were
needed. Staff 1 reported she was watching the youth during
dinner and Youth A went into the parking lot and sat down. She
reported the other youth began playing football and when looking
for Youth A, Youth A had “just disappeared”. She told another staff
who she could not recall which staff and went back to the spot
where she was sitting. She reported being told by another youth
who she could not recall which youth, that Youth A went into the
bushes behind the volleyball court. She reported being able to see
part of Youth A’s jacket, so she and Staff 2 walked over to Youth
A and asked Youth A what Youth A was doing. She reported
Youth A only said Youth A was “ok” and didn’t want to go inside.
They left Youth A there and went back inside. She reported going
back outside around 8-8:30PM and having Youth A continue to
refuse to respond to her questions. Staff 2 told her the next
morning that staff looked for Youth A but were unable to find him.
She reported Supervisor informed staff through text messages,
that they were not to chase Youth A because the facility was short
staffed at the time. She reported prior to leaving work, she
observed Youth A outside without supervision by staff for 40-45
minutes. She believed staff checked on Youth A every 20 minutes
because Staff 2 told her so. When returning to work the next
3

morning she was surprised to see Youth A speaking with Case
Manager Supervisor inside. Staff 1 did not report checking on
Youth A during the evening.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 10/23/2024. She reported
working second shift the day of the incident and was unsure of
what occurred for Youth A to refuse to reenter the building. She
reported Youth A has a history of being unpredictable when Youth
A is angry and will refuse to reenter the building. Staff 3 reported
checking on Youth A a “couple of times” during the shift and
having Youth A tell her each time Youth A was alright and didn’t
want to reenter the building. She was unable to recall the specific
times she checked on Youth A but believed it could have been 2-3
times. She reported she would check the video monitors at times
and look out of the window at other times. She reported rotating
with Staff 1, Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 to check on Youth A. She
was unsure if any written logs were completed and had contact
with Supervisor. Supervisor informed Staff 3 to check on Youth A
and convince Youth A to come inside. She reported Youth A was
in the same spot until she left work at 11PM.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 10/23/2024. She reported
working second shift the day of the incident. She reported Youth A
was outside and didn’t want to come inside. She reported this is
not the first time Youth A has refused to return to the building. She
reported there were 16 or 17 youth in the program at the time with
only 4 staff after 8PM so staff needed to stay in ratio with the other
youth. Staff had other duties such as discharge paperwork,
chores, and phone calls for youth. Staff 4 also reported the staff
left Youth A outside unattended, only checking on Youth A when
they were able to find Youth A randomly. She reported Supervisor
told her staff should leave Youth A and go upstairs with the other
youth and check on Youth A every half hour. She reported
checking on Youth A three times. She did not know if there was
written documentation of checks being completed on Youth A at
this time. When she left work at 11PM Youth A was still outside.
She reported normally bed checks need to occur no more than
every 15-minutes.
Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 10/23/2024. She reported
working second shift on the day of the incident and stated Youth A
was refusing to enter the building as reported earlier by other staff.
She reported there were only 4 staff present and 17 youth to
supervise so staff had to be inside to pass medication, do chores,
phone calls, and paperwork. She reported staff continued to check
on Youth A every half hour and would continue to ask Youth A to
4

come inside. She reported only checking on Youth A at 10:45PM
but believed other staff checked on Youth A more often. She
reported overhearing Supervisor tell staff they should check on
Youth A every half hour. She reported there is a video monitor on
the floor so staff could look to see if Youth A came back to the
building. When she left at 11PM she “caught” site of Youth A in
the same spot (sitting behind a tree near the volleyball court) but
didn’t walk over and speak with Youth A.
Staff 2 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024. He reported
working second shift the evening of the incident. He reported
around 7PM the youth would go downstairs for dinner and at this
time Youth A put on headphones while watching other youth play
football. When the youth came back inside, Staff 2 noticed Youth
A was missing from the group. An unidentified coworker as Staff 2
could not remember the staff told Staff 2 that Youth A walked
towards the volleyball court. Staff 2 went to the volleyball court
and found Youth A sitting in the woods near the court. Staff 2
reported telling Youth A it was time to go inside and begin
cleaning the dining room and kitchen. Youth A refused so Staff 2
left him and called Supervisor. Staff 2 reported Supervisor
informed Staff 2 that there were not enough staff working at the
time so they could leave Youth A outside and check on Youth A
every 25-30 minutes. Supervisor told Staff 2 that staff could check
the video monitor to see if Youth A shows up and then let Youth A
in the building. Staff 2 reported staff checked on Youth A every
30-minutes, but Youth A continued to refuse to return to the
building. Staff 2 reported Case Manager Supervisor was
contacted and attempted to speak to Youth A by phone, but Youth
A refused to speak. This is reported to have occurred around
10:45PM. Staff 2 reported the checks were not documented but a
text message was sent to Supervisor every time a check on Youth
A was made. Staff 2 reported when leaving, he observed Youth A
in the same spot.
Staff 6 was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024. He reported
working third shift the night of the incident and when coming on
shift the second shift staff (unable to recall the name of the staff)
informed him to call Supervisor because Youth A was refusing to
come inside. Staff 6 reported Staff 7 called Supervisor and
Supervisor informed them to watch the video monitor to see if
Youth A comes back to the building. Supervisor told staff to watch
the video monitor every 20 minutes which Staff 6 didn’t like. Staff
6 reported not liking these directions and went outside once to
check on Youth A but was unable to find Youth A. He reported
Staff 7 went outside once but also could not find Youth A.
5

Supervisor then told the two staff not to go outside because of the
ratio and to just check the video monitor. Staff 6 also reported
Staff 7 told Staff 6 they were not to check outside because they
had youth to supervise in the building. Staff 6 also reported Staff 7
called Supervisor and Staff 7 passed the information from
Supervisor along to Staff 6. He reported there was no staff outside
with Youth A when he arrived for his shift. Staff 6 reported Youth A
came inside around 7:30AM with Case Manager Supervisor.
Staff 7 was interviewed via phone on 11/25/2024. He reported
he remembers the incident with Youth A and worker. He reported
being told by Staff 4 and Staff 5 of the situation with Youth A and
Youth A refusal to reenter the building. Staff 4 and Staff 5 reported
to have told Staff 7 that Supervisor will call them with directions on
how to handle the situation. Rather than wait, Staff 7 reported
calling Supervisor and being told that Staff 6 and Staff 7 need to
stay in the building and supervisor the other youth because if they
left, they would be out of ratio. He reported being told by
Supervisor to check the camera every 30-40 minutes and
document what they observed in the shift log. He described the
shift log like a “room check log”. Staff 7 reported telling Supervisor
that he was unable to see clearly in the camera view and could
only make out shadows because of the weather and lack of light.
At one point, Staff 7 went outside and attempted to find Youth A
but was unsuccessful. After returning to the building, Staff 7
informed Staff 6 who then went outside but was also unsuccessful
in locating Youth A. Staff 7 reported this occurred around 4:00am
and he called Supervisor to inform Supervisor that they were
unable to locate Youth A. Staff 7 reported not being aware of the
location of the log he documented camera checks on but that he
did document when going outside to look for Youth A. Staff 7
reported having numerous chores to do. Overall, Staff 7 reported
having only 2 phone calls with Supervisor.
Supervisor was interviewed via phone on 10/24/2024. He
reported receiving a phone call from Staff 2 at 7:45PM informing
him that Youth A was refusing to come back inside the building.
The youth had finished dinner and were engaged in doing chores
before going back upstairs to get ready for bed. Supervisor
reported asking Staff 2 if Youth A was escalated and what was the
reason for Youth A’s refusal to come inside. Staff 2 informed
Supervisor that Youth A was calm and listening to music but
refused to speak or acknowledge anyone. Supervisor was told
Youth A was sitting at a picnic table far away from the cafeteria
and since it was dark at the time, staff couldn’t see Youth A unless
they went to the area. Supervisor reported asking staff (unable to
6

recall which staff) if someone could sit in the cafeteria and watch
Youth A but was informed it was too dark to see Youth A from the
cafeteria. Supervisor knew they had limited staff at the time, so he
instructed staff to check on Youth A every 30-minutes because
safety and care for the other youth was primary. Supervisor
reported the facility has a ratio of 1:6 during the day and 1:12
during sleeping hours. Because two second shift staff called in
sick, he had Staff 1 stay until 8PM. There were 17 youth present
at the time and 4 staff on second shift and 2 staff on third shift
leaving no extra staff to check on Youth A after Staff 1 left at 8PM.
Supervisor reported telling staff that if Youth A moves or
something changes, they were to call Supervisor. Supervisor
reported telling Staff 2 to document the check in the observation
logs as well as texting Supervisor. Supervisor reported receiving
text messages every half hour and will provide these text
messages. He reported speaking to Clinician who agreed to
facilitate a phone call with Youth A. Supervisor reported writing an
incident report on 10/10/24 and notifying ORR on 10/9/24 of the
AWOL of Youth A.
Clinician was interviewed via phone on 11/5/2024. She
reported being informed by Supervisor of the situation with Youth
A refusing to return to the building. She also reported informing
staff (unable to recall which staff) that she should be notified if
Youth A leaves the area but did want to give Youth A some alone
time outside because Youth A likes to spend time outside. She
reported this contact with the facility occurred around 10 to
10:30PM and she was thinking of driving to the facility but chose
to make a video call with Youth A. Youth A refused to speak with
Clinician on the video call. She reported making the decision not
to drive in because staff (unable to recall which staff) told her the
video call was the best option. Clinician reported having no more
contact with staff at the facility the rest of the night after the failed
video call. She reported believing staff were checking on Youth A
every 10-15 minutes and was surprised to learn staff were
informed to only check on Youth A every 30-minutes.
Documents Reviewed:
Bethany Christian services Transitional Assessment Center
Transitional Living Center Policies & Procedures – Staff to
Resident Policy dated 8/3/2023. It is documented that if youth
are out of the direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform
variable interval, eye-on checks of the youth not to exceed 15-
minutes. This document also states that during awake hours there
7

should be one staff for every eight youth and during overnight
hours there should be one staff for every sixteen youth.
Communication log (text) between on-call staff and staff at
the facility on 10/8/24 regarding Youth A staying outside.
These messages only involve the following staff: Supervisor, Case
Manager Supervisor, and Staff 7. No other staff are identified as
being involved in this stream of messages. There is also no
documentation of any checks being made on Youth A throughout
these messages. Supervisor notes he will not have staff to check
on youth.
Bridgeway Transitional Assessment Center Client
Observation Log dated 10/8/24. This documents checks are
being completed at times where there are not varying intervals
and multiple times exceeding 15 minutes when youth are asleep
or otherwise outside the line of sight of staff.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as based on interviews
with staff and written documentation staff did not provide the
required supervision of Youth A while Youth A was out of the line
of sight. Even though, the facility had enough staff on duty during
second shift at the time of this incident, Supervisor instructed staff
to focus on the youth in the building rather than provide a staff for
the supervision of Youth A. The facility’s policy on staff to youth
states the ratio is to be 1 staff for 8 youth during waking hours and
during second shift there were 4 staff on duty for 16 or 17 youth
which is a ratio of 4.25 youth per staff. Therefor, 3 staff could have
provided supervision within ratio allowing the 4th staff to supervise
Youth A. Additionally, the room check log supports that the facility
is not engaging in variable random room checks not exceeding 15
minutes.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered regarding the duties of staff
when supervising youth. It appears as reported by some of the
staff interviewed that staff have numerous duties to conduct while
also providing supervision to the youth. It is recommended that
staff are trained and understand that their primary duty is the
supervision of youth above any other duties. Only after
appropriate supervision is completed should staff engage in other
duties. If the duties are required to be completed during the time
staff are to also supervise, then the facility needs to increase the
number of staff working the shift so there is no gap in the
supervision required.
8

Technical assistance was offered regarding the duties of on-call
staff. It is recommended that as a part of the on-call staff’s duties
is the requirement of coming to the facility to present a physical
presence to ensure the appropriate supervision is being applied.
Being on site will also add support to the staff working and help in
resolving any issues without question.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Incident reporting
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150
Section (3) If an institution determines that a youth is absent without legal
Description permission, then the institution shall immediately report the
information to law enforcement, the parent/legal guardian or next
of kin, the licensing authority, and the referring agency.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Facility failed to notify licensing about Youth A going AWOL until 2
days after the incident.
Investigation Case Manager Supervisor were interviewed face-to-face at
the facility on 10/10/2024. Case Manager Supervisor reported
that she was in the process of notifying the licensing consultant of
the AWOL but had yet to inform the licensing consultant. She
reported beginning the AWOL process at 5:30AM of 10/10/24
when being informed of Youth A being AWOL on 10/8/2024.
Case Manager Supervisor was interviewed again via phone
on 11/4/2024. She reported becoming involved around 5:45AM
when Supervisor called her to inform her that staff were unable to
locate Youth A, so Case Manager Supervisor began the AWOL
process at that time. She called Law Enforcement and Supervisor
was to call the other required numbers.
Licensing Consultant was interviewed via phone on
11/12/2024. She reported being notified by email of Youth A’s
AWOL statues on 10/10/24 at 12:16 pm.
Documents Reviewed:
Bethany Christian services Transitional Assessment Center
Transitional Living Center Policies & Procedures -
AWOL/Runaway Procedure Policy dated 9/16/24. This
document outlines the procedure for the prevention of a runaway
situation. It is documented that if a youth has been identified with
the potential to run away after-hours, on-call is to be notified
9

immediately. A face-to-face intervention should occur and is to be
conducted by either the on-call worker or the program therapist, or
an on-shift staff with the assistance of the on-call worker, to
assess the safety of the youth. It is documented that after hours,
on-call and shift supervisor are to coordinate the response to
AWOL and the Clinician or on-call clinician should conduct the
AWOL Risk Assessment to determine flight risk and safety plan
accordingly. Once confirming the youth is AWOL, the response
team notify State Licensing. This document states that if the youth
is a UC youth, then the AWOL process does not begin until the
youth doesn’t return for 4-hours.
AWOL Risk Assessment dated 10/8/2024 for Youth A. This
document outlines that Clinician assessed Youth A for being an
AWOL risk assessment. It is documented Youth A informed
Clinician Youth A was not planning on going AWOL and Youth A
refused to respond to any further questions.
Analysis The agency is found in noncompliance as based on interviews
with Case Manager Supervisor, Licensing Consultant and written
documentation the Licensing Consultant was not notified of Youth
A’s AWOL statues until 2-days after the incident.
Technical Assistance
Technical assistance was offered to update policy as 4 hours is
too long to wait to consider a youth AWOL as staff need to check
on them in varying intervals not to exceed 15 minutes.
Conclusion Violation Established
10

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
